messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 59 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: A New Information Complexity Measure for Multi-pass Streaming with Applications

Paper Abstract: Abstract We introduce a new notion of information complexity for multi-pass streaming problems and use it to resolve several important questions in data streams: 1. In the coin problem, one sees a stream of nùëõn i.i.d. uniform bits and one would like to compute the majority with constant advantage. We show that any constant pass algorithm must use Œ©‚Äã(log‚Å°n)Œ©ùëõ\Omega(\log n) bits of memory, significantly extending an earlier Œ©‚Äã(log‚Å°n)Œ©ùëõ\Omega(\log n) bit lower bound for single-pass algorithms of Braverman-Garg-Woodruff (FOCS, 2020). This also gives the first Œ©‚Äã(log‚Å°n)Œ©ùëõ\Omega(\log n) bit lower bound for the problem of approximating a counter up to a constant factor in worst-case turnstile streams for more than one pass. 2. In the needle problem, one either sees a stream of nùëõn i.i.d. uniform samples from a domain [t]delimited-[]ùë°[t], or there is a randomly chosen ‚Äúneedle" Œ±‚àà[t]ùõºdelimited-[]ùë°\alpha\in[t] for which each item independently is chosen to equal Œ±ùõº\alpha with probability pùëùp, and is otherwise uniformly random in [t]delimited-[]ùë°[t]. The problem of distinguishing these two cases is central to understanding the space complexity of the frequency moment estimation problem in random order streams. We show tight multi-pass space bounds for this problem for every p<1/n‚Äãlog3‚Å°nùëù1ùëõsuperscript3ùëõp<1/\sqrt{n\log^{3}n}, resolving an open question of Lovett and Zhang (FOCS, 2023); even for 111-pass our bounds are new. To show optimality, we improve both lower and upper bounds from existing results. Our information complexity framework significantly extends the toolkit for proving multi-pass streaming lower bounds, and we give a wide number of additional streaming applications of our lower bound techniques, including multi-pass lower bounds for ‚Ñìpsubscript‚Ñìùëù\ell_{p}-norm estimation, ‚Ñìpsubscript‚Ñìùëù\ell_{p}-point query and heavy hitters, and compressed sensing problems.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 59 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 59"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "The white-box adversarial data stream model",
        "New characterizations in turnstile streams with applications",
        "On the amortized complexity of approximate counting",
        "Streaming algorithms via precision sampling",
        "Multi-pass graph streaming lower bounds for cycle counting, max-cut, matching size, and other problems",
        "Better bounds for frequency moments in random-order streams",
        "The space complexity of approximating the frequency moments",
        "Strong memory lower bounds for learning natural models",
        "Bptree: An ùìÅùìÅ\\mathscr{l}22{}_{\\mbox{2}} heavy hitters algorithm using constant memory",
        "Beating countsketch for heavy hitters in insertion streams",
        "On a modification of chebyshev‚Äôs inequality and of the error formula of laplace",
        "On certain modifications of chebyshev‚Äôs inequality",
        "Simpler algorithm for estimating frequency moments of data streams",
        "The coin problem with applications to data streams",
        "Tight space complexity of the coin problem",
        "An information statistics approach to data stream and communication complexity",
        "An optimal algorithm for large frequency moments using ùí™‚Äã(n1‚àí2/k)ùí™superscriptùëõ12ùëò\\mathcal{O}(n^{1-2/k}) bits",
        "Robust lower bounds for communication and stream computation",
        "The maximum of a random walk and its application to rectangle packing",
        "A measure of asymptotic efficiency for tests of a hypothesis based on the sum of observations",
        "Tight lower bounds for selection in randomly ordered streams",
        "Near-optimal lower bounds on the multi-party communication complexity of set disjointness",
        "Stochastic streams: Sample complexity vs. space complexity",
        "Memory-efficient algorithms for finding needles in haystacks",
        "Communication and memory efficient testing of discrete distributions",
        "On the streaming indistinguishability of a random permutation and a random function",
        "Approximate maximum matching in random streams",
        "Approximate counting: A detailed analysis",
        "Polynomial estimators for high frequency moments",
        "Revisiting the direct sum theorem and space lower bounds in random order streams",
        "For-all sparse recovery in near-optimal time",
        "Space-efficient sampling",
        "Stream order and order statistics: Quantile estimation in random-order streams",
        "Asymptotically optimal lower bounds on the nih-multi-party information, 2009.",
        "Information Complexity and Data Stream Algorithms for Basic Problems",
        "High Probability Frequency Moment Sketches",
        "On the power of adaptivity in sparse recovery",
        "Optimal approximations of the frequency moments of data streams",
        "Hellinger strikes back: A note on the multi-party information complexity of and",
        "Tight time-memory trade-offs for symmetric encryption",
        "Data streams with bounded deletions",
        "Towards optimal moment estimation in streaming and distributed models",
        "On the exact space complexity of sketching and streaming small norms",
        "A simple proof of a new set disjointness with applications to data streams",
        "Streaming lower bounds and asymmetric set-disjointness",
        "On data structures and asymmetric communication complexity",
        "Space-efficient estimation of statistics over sub-sampled streams",
        "1-pass relative-error lp-sampling with applications",
        "Beating the direct sum theorem in communication complexity with implications for sketching",
        "Improved algorithms for adaptive compressed sensing",
        "Optimal bounds for approximate counting",
        "(1 + eps)-approximate sparse recovery",
        "Lower bounds for adaptive sparse recovery",
        "Fast learning requires good memory: A time-space lower bound for parity learning",
        "Counting large numbers of events in small registers",
        "Memory-sample tradeoffs for linear regression with small error",
        "Provable time-memory trade-offs: Symmetric cryptography against memory-bounded adversaries",
        "The communication complexity of addition",
        "Separations for estimating large frequency moments on data streams"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 59 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in A New Information Complexity Measure for Multi-pass Streaming with Applications, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
